For each simulated sample we form t-statistics for the dierence between the bootstrapped estimate of the coe cient and the original point estimate. Suppose the empirically observed t-statistic in the main estimate for some coe cient k is equal to ^ tk > 0. Then the bootstrapped p-value is twice the fraction of the simulated t-statistics at least as high as ^ tk (for a full description of the procedure, see Efron and Tibshirani, 1994)
